The Weekly Mail.

HEADWAROINE.

A special meeting of the City Council last Friday evening. Ald. Johnson, Backe, Davis, Hughes, Cameron, Adams and Lee were present.

The special committee for the purpose of raising $300 for the city charter said that Mr. Enfield would take $300 for his scales, in a note of five months, with interest, or he would rent it at $150 a year. Ald. Johnson approved of the parcel of land offered by Mr. Enfield wanted to know the actual value before agreeing.

Uncle omnibus.

Last Thursday, Frank Myers, of Portage la Prairie, was playing pool against others in the city hall poolroom. The game was interrupted by a loud noise coming from the city hall poolroom. The noise was caused by the city hall poolroom being crowded with spectators. The spectators were cheering on their favorite player.

Last Saturday night, Frank Myers, of Portage la Prairie, won a game of pool against others in the city hall poolroom. The game was interrupted by a loud noise coming from the city hall poolroom. The noise was caused by the city hall poolroom being crowded with spectators. The spectators were cheering on their favorite player.

An Excellent Appointment.

The many friends of Mr. Alex. McKeown will be pleased to learn that Mr. McKeown has been appointed as an employee of the Manitoba Government. Mr. McKeown has been a resident of this country for many years and has always been interested in the welfare of the people. He has been connected with various organizations and has always taken a moderate interest in municipal and general politics. Mr. McKeown's appointment is a well-deserved honor and we have no doubt that he will prove himself a valuable addition to our ranks.

The Portage has 525 children attending school this fall, 250 more than last year. Of these 460 have attended school during the past year. Mr. Backe said that there was no lack of attendance at the Portage School for the past year.

Portage has 525 children attending school this fall, 250 more than last year. Of these 460 have attended school during the past year. Mr. Backe said that there was no lack of attendance at the Portage School for the past year.

A Maiden Fair.

CHAPTER VI.

A WILD NIGHT.

Although the afternoon had ended in summer, the evening changed to winter. Snowy clouds gathered in the sky, and the sun set behind the hills, and crowds gathered in the streets, but only abated during the day. Night came, and the moon rose, but the clouds still lingered above, and the stars twinkled in the sky. The wind howled, and the trees swayed in the gusts. The air was cold, and the people huddled together, seeking shelter from the elements. The weather was harsh, and the people were forced to seek warmth wherever they could find it.

The next day dawned bright and clear, and the people emerged from their shelters, eager to begin their day's work. The streets were busy, and the shops were bustling with activity. The people were determined to make the most of the day, despite the harsh weather.

The story continues...
A REMINISCENCE

of the Assassination of Abraham Lincoln.

The Martyr's Body Brought

to Brandon by Mr. Hume.

The Terrible Affair in God's

Presence.

(Washington Star.)

The President's body was brought to Brandon last night by Mr. Hume, who had been engaged in the service of the late President. The body was placed in a casket and carried to the Brandon Hotel by a party of prominent citizens. The body was then placed in a hearse and driven to the Brandon Cemetery. The body was then placed in a vault and will be interred there.

BRASS KNUCKLES BANDED.

Society—Gentlemen's Clubs—An Innovation in Finger Wear.

The New York Journal.

Brass knuckles have been introduced into society as an innovation in finger wear. They are no longer tolerated. At a recent dinner party a gentleman wore them at table. It is a curious thing that they have been in use for a long time past, but nobody twenty years ago thought of wearing them at dinner parties. When they first came into fashion, they were considered unsightly without their aid, and now that they are worn, they are bound to be seen even in the most polished circles. The brass knuckles are made of heavy metal and amount of skill which now characterizes the art of making them. They are not only extremely useful, but also very effective. They are made in various sizes, from the smallest to the largest, and are worn on the fingers. They are made of brass, and are very durable. They are worn on the fingers, and are very effective when used properly.

NOTICE

TO SUBSCRIBERS.

As we are endeavoring to settle the subscription list of the MAIL promptly as far as possible, so as to enable us to fill all offices promptly, we make the following proposition: From those who took the paper from the First January, 1883, and have paid nothing since, we will

ACCEPT $5

AND

GIVE A CLEAR RECEIPT to January, 1886, that is, receipt all arrears, and pay one year in advance.

From those who commenced in September, 1883, the first under present manage-
ment, and have since paid nothing, we will

ACCEPT $8.50

to fall to January, 1886, that is, receipt all arrears, and pay one year and balance of this in advance, and from those who paid the present proposition last year, and whose term has not expired some weeks hence, we will accept $2, and receipt until January, 1886. To those who paid two or three years in advance, and have never been late in paying their paper, and who have been subscribers of the First of the Provinces, and very worthy of the patronage of all independent-minded people, we will accept $1.50, and receipt until January, 1886. In addition, however, all uncollected subscriptions at that time will be placed on our subscriber's hands, and they will be charged at the rate of $1.50 per month, payable, etc., etc., every month, and we have no reason why we should be asked to give a year credit or more. These terms will be strictly enforced.

C. CLIFFE.
Publisher

Notice.
Notice is hereby given that the Corporation of the City of Brandon will hold an election on the 25th day of November next, for the purpose of electing a Mayor and Aldermen. The polls will be opened at 9 o'clock A.M., and will close at 8 o'clock P.M. All citizens who are entitled to vote are respectfully requested to attend.

Civic Election.

To the Citizens of the City of Brandon:

Gentlemen:

I have the honor to inform you that the Honorable Mr. Smith has been appointed by the Board of Trade to take charge of the affairs of the City of Brandon. He will be responsible for the management of all matters pertaining to the City, and will be expected to give his utmost attention and best efforts to the welfare of the citizens.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

A. M. STEPHENSON

---

**MORE CONGRATULATIONS**

An informal meeting of the Brandon Conservative Association following the election, which springs for itself, was unanimously addressed by Mr. Alexander E. F. Burt, seconded by Mr. Spence, that this successful meeting, surpassing all expectations regarding the question at hand, will be held at the home of Mr. John A. Macdonald, commemorating the fact that, in view of the advantages of political life, it is the duty of every man who has an interest in the City and County of Brandon, by grasping this opportunity to elect a friend, and thus assuring a true friend to represent them at every calling.

It is therefore resolved that the Brandon Conservative Association hereby appoint a delegate to attend at the detention to be held next week at the home of Mr. John A. Macdonald, at the City of Brandon, for the purpose of forming a club eighteenth of December instant.

After this resolution had been read by Hon. D. M. Wainwright, it was moved by Mr. Smith and seconded by Mr. John A. Macdonald, that this Club should be known by the name of the Conservative Association of the County and City of Brandon, and that a calling card be sent to every house in the City and County to be delivered at the office of the Tory. This motion was carried by unanimous vote.

This will be a great carnival of an eco-patriotic nature, and the most enthusiastic spirit will be manifested by those present.

It was further resolved that the Club should raise enough money to purchase a band, as the Union Band is doing, and that they should be able to make an arrangement with Bertoni to supply them with a band, at a cost of five cents per member each year.

That these resolutions be acted upon forthwith.

---

**ANTI-FAT**

Alderman McCollins this week returned from his southern tour, visiting New Orleans and many other points east and south. Mr. Adams has made a profitable trip, to say the least, bringing back some excellent bargains for his paper.

---

**MARKET REPORT**

The market has been unusually quiet, and there has been a dearth of transactions. The market will be inactive until the fall prices come into vogue. The market for poultry is decreasing, although prices are still quite high.

---

**TOWN TOPICS**

The Fire Department is now in the hands of the newly appointed Fire Chief, Mr. James Murray. Under his leadership, the department has been strengthened and improved.

The Brandon Orchestra will give its annual concert on Christmas Eve, with special works by Beethoven and Mozart.

---

**MAJOR EVENTS**

Major Douglas and Lieutenant Burrows departed last Monday on a trip through the West. They will stop in Regina for a few days before returning to Brandon.

The Brandon Council will hold a full council meeting on Wednesday evening, with the Mayor presiding.

Major Burrows met with Premier Medawar on the Prairies earlier this month, discussing matters of mutual concern.

---

**LOCAL NEWS**

The Brandon Press Club has announced plans to hold its annual banquet on New Year's Eve. The evening will feature music, speeches, and refreshments.

The Brandon Ladies' Aid Society has initiated a fund-raising campaign to help support the local orphanage.

---

**PERSONAL NEWS**

James Smart has begun a leave of absence to spend the holiday season with his family in the southwest. He will return early in January.

The Moose Club is preparing for its annual ball, scheduled for this weekend. Tickets are available at the Moose Hall.

Judge Walker will have invited guests stay at the Brandon Inn for the upcoming week-end. The Inn will also host a large film marathon featuring classic movies.

---

**ADDITIONAL CONTENT**

The Brandon Weekly Mail is a weekly newspaper serving the Brandon, Manitoba community. It covers local news, events, and Announcements.
